elem_6.grade_description: Elementary school 6th grade writers. Students at this level are beginning to write short compositions in English. They have limited exposure to English writing and rely on basic sentence patterns learned in class.

beginner.description: Elementary school 6th grade, beginner writer. Can produce only the most basic sentences with heavy reliance on memorized patterns.

criteria.content: Simple daily topics only (e.g., family, pets, food). Ideas are very basic and undeveloped, often just listing facts. Little to no elaboration or personal opinion.
criteria.organization: Almost no clear structure. Sentences may appear in random order with no logical flow. No recognizable introduction or conclusion.
criteria.vocabulary: Very limited vocabulary (under 100 active words). Relies on extremely basic, high-frequency words. Frequent L1 interference and word-choice errors.
criteria.grammar: Frequent grammar errors that often impede understanding. Struggles with basic subject-verb agreement, verb tenses, and articles. Sentences are mostly simple (S+V+O).

intermediate.description: Elementary school 6th grade, intermediate writer. Can express simple but complete ideas about familiar topics with some coherence.

criteria.content: Simple but complete ideas about familiar topics (e.g., school life, hobbies). Includes at least one supporting detail or reason. Shows some personal voice.
criteria.organization: Some structure with a basic beginning and end. Ideas generally follow a logical order, though transitions are absent or very basic (and, but, so).
criteria.vocabulary: Basic vocabulary with a few varied words beyond the most common ones. Occasional attempts at descriptive words. Some repetition but generally appropriate word choice.
criteria.grammar: Some errors but overall understandable. Can form simple and some compound sentences correctly. Errors in tense consistency and prepositions are common but do not block meaning.

advanced.description: Elementary school 6th grade, advanced writer. Produces well-developed short essays with clear structure on familiar topics.

criteria.content: Well-developed ideas about familiar topics with supporting details and examples. Shows clear personal opinion or perspective. Ideas are relevant and focused.
criteria.organization: Clear beginning, middle, and end. Ideas flow logically within paragraphs. Uses basic transition words effectively (first, then, also, finally).
criteria.vocabulary: Varied vocabulary within everyday topics. Uses some adjectives and adverbs for description. Word choice is generally accurate and appropriate for the context.
criteria.grammar: Mostly correct grammar with minor errors. Can use both simple and compound sentences. Consistent verb tense within a passage. Minor errors with articles or prepositions.
criteria.length: 60–80 words. Typically 6–8 sentences with some variety in length.

master.description: Elementary school 6th grade, master-level writer. Produces polished, engaging writing that exceeds grade-level expectations.

criteria.content: Rich and detailed ideas even for simple topics. Includes vivid examples and personal reflections. Writing is engaging and shows creativity appropriate for the age group.
criteria.organization: Very clear and logical structure with smooth flow between ideas. Opening grabs attention, body develops ideas well, and closing provides a satisfying end.
criteria.vocabulary: Rich and appropriate vocabulary for this age. Uses descriptive language effectively. Minimal repetition. Occasionally uses less common words accurately.
criteria.grammar: Almost no grammar errors. Varied sentence structures including simple, compound, and occasionally complex sentences. Excellent control of basic grammar rules.
criteria.length: 80–100 words. Typically 8–12 sentences with good variety in sentence length and structure.

mid_2.grade_description: Middle school 2nd grade writers. Students have studied English for several years and are developing the ability to express opinions and construct basic arguments in writing.

beginner.description: Middle school 2nd grade, beginner writer. Can state a simple opinion but struggles to develop or support it coherently.

criteria.content: Very simple opinions with only 1 weak or vague reason. Ideas lack depth and may be off-topic or circular. No clear examples or evidence to support claims.
criteria.organization: Loose structure with ideas that may jump around. No clear distinction between introduction, body, and conclusion. Lacks transitions between ideas.
criteria.vocabulary: Basic and repetitive vocabulary. Limited range makes it hard to express nuanced ideas. Relies heavily on common words and may misuse some terms.
criteria.grammar: Frequent errors that affect readability. Struggles with complex sentence structures. Errors in subject-verb agreement, tense consistency, and word order are common.
criteria.length: 50–80 words. Typically 4–6 sentences, mostly short and simple.

intermediate.description: Middle school 2nd grade, intermediate writer. Can express opinions with basic supporting reasons and some organizational awareness.

criteria.content: Simple opinions with 1–2 supporting reasons. Some attempt at providing examples, though they may be vague or generic. Shows awareness of the need to persuade or explain.
criteria.organization: Some sense of introduction and conclusion. Body paragraphs exist but may be underdeveloped. Uses a few basic transitions (however, for example, because).
criteria.vocabulary: Basic vocabulary with some variety. Attempts to use topic-specific words. Occasional word-choice errors but generally conveys intended meaning.
criteria.grammar: Noticeable errors but overall understandable. Can form compound sentences with conjunctions. Some attempts at complex sentences (because, when, if) with mixed success.
criteria.length: 80–120 words. Typically 6–10 sentences across 1–2 short paragraphs.

advanced.description: Middle school 2nd grade, advanced writer. Produces clear, well-organized opinion essays with solid supporting arguments.

criteria.content: Clear opinions with 2–3 well-developed supporting reasons. Includes specific examples or evidence. Arguments are logical and stay on topic throughout.
criteria.organization: Recognizable introduction (with thesis), body (with developed paragraphs), and conclusion. Effective use of transitions to connect ideas across paragraphs.
criteria.vocabulary: Varied vocabulary including some abstract and academic words. Word choice enhances the argument. Minimal repetition with appropriate synonyms used.
criteria.grammar: Mostly correct grammar with occasional minor errors. Handles both compound and complex sentences well. Good control of tense, agreement, and basic punctuation.
criteria.length: 120–150 words. Typically 10–14 sentences across 2–3 well-developed paragraphs.

master.description: Middle school 2nd grade, master-level writer. Produces persuasive, well-crafted essays that demonstrate strong critical thinking.

criteria.content: Well-developed, persuasive argument with clear examples and logical reasoning. May acknowledge counterarguments. Writing shows critical thinking and genuine engagement with the topic.
criteria.organization: Very clear logical flow with effective paragraphing. Strong introduction with a compelling thesis, well-structured body paragraphs, and a thoughtful conclusion that goes beyond simple restatement.
criteria.vocabulary: Rich vocabulary including appropriate academic and topic-specific words. Precise word choice that strengthens arguments. Uses collocations and phrases naturally.
criteria.grammar: Very few or no errors. Varied and sophisticated sentence structures. Excellent control of complex sentences, relative clauses, and conditional forms.
criteria.length: 150–200 words. Typically 12–18 sentences across 3–4 well-crafted paragraphs.

high_2.grade_description: High school 2nd grade writers. Students are expected to write extended argumentative and analytical essays. They should demonstrate ability to construct nuanced arguments with evidence and handle abstract topics.

beginner.description: High school 2nd grade, beginner writer. Can attempt argumentative writing but lacks the skills to develop ideas fully or organize them effectively.

criteria.content: Basic opinions with limited and shallow support. Arguments lack depth, specificity, and logical development. May include irrelevant information or unsupported generalizations.
criteria.organization: Weak structure with unclear transitions between ideas. Paragraphs may be absent or poorly defined. Introduction and conclusion are minimal or missing.
criteria.vocabulary: Limited vocabulary for handling abstract or academic topics. Relies on simple, everyday words even when discussing complex ideas. Frequent word-choice errors.
criteria.grammar: Frequent errors, especially in complex sentence structures. Struggles with subordinate clauses, passive voice, and advanced punctuation. Errors often affect clarity.
criteria.length: 100–150 words. Typically 8–12 sentences, mostly simple structures with occasional compound sentences.

intermediate.description: High school 2nd grade, intermediate writer. Can construct basic arguments with some development but lacks consistency in quality.

criteria.content: Some clear arguments but not fully developed. Provides supporting reasons but examples may be generic or insufficient. Shows awareness of complexity but doesn't fully explore it.
criteria.organization: Recognizable essay structure but with uneven paragraph development. Some transitions present but may be formulaic (firstly, secondly, in conclusion). Ideas occasionally drift.
criteria.vocabulary: Adequate vocabulary with some variety. Can use some abstract and academic terms, though not always accurately. Occasional reliance on overly simple language for the grade level.
criteria.grammar: Some errors in complex structures but generally understandable. Can produce compound-complex sentences with partial success. Inconsistent control of advanced grammar features.

advanced.description: High school 2nd grade, advanced writer. Produces well-structured argumentative essays with relevant evidence and clear reasoning.

criteria.content: Well-structured arguments with relevant examples and clear reasoning. Demonstrates good analytical thinking. May include some consideration of alternative viewpoints.
criteria.organization: Clear introduction with thesis, well-developed body paragraphs with topic sentences, and a strong conclusion. Effective transitions create smooth flow throughout the essay.
criteria.vocabulary: Good range of vocabulary including abstract terms, academic language, and topic-specific words. Word choice is precise and enhances the argument. Uses collocations appropriately.
criteria.grammar: Generally accurate with complex sentences handled well. Good control of relative clauses, conditionals, passive voice, and varied sentence openers. Minor errors only.
criteria.length: 200–250 words. Typically 16–20 sentences across 4–5 well-structured paragraphs.

master.description: High school 2nd grade, master-level writer. Produces sophisticated, nuanced essays that demonstrate near-native writing proficiency.

criteria.content: Sophisticated, nuanced arguments with strong, well-chosen evidence. Demonstrates critical thinking, considers counterarguments, and presents a compelling, original perspective.
criteria.organization: Excellent cohesion and coherence throughout. Seamless transitions, well-balanced paragraph structure, and a conclusion that synthesizes ideas rather than simply restating them.
criteria.vocabulary: Rich, precise vocabulary appropriate to academic writing. Uses hedging language, formal register, and sophisticated expressions naturally. Demonstrates strong command of collocations and idiomatic usage.
criteria.grammar: Near-native control of grammar and sentence structure. Employs a wide range of complex structures naturally, including inversions, cleft sentences, and advanced subordination. Virtually error-free.
criteria.length: 220–280 words. Typically 18–24 sentences across 4–5 polished paragraphs with varied sentence lengths.
